title: What are some of the best 90s alternative rock songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah, yes - the '90s. I'm biased, because I was in my 20s for most of it, but I think the music stands up pretty well to the test of time. Maybe not all of this stuff is considered alternative rock, I don't know - but it works for me! Here are some great tunes. Enjoy. Jane's Addiction, "Three Days" (from Ritual de lo Habitual, 1990)  The Pixies, "The Happening" (from Bossanova, 1990)  Throwing Muses, "Dizzy" (from Hunkpapa, 1990)  Lush "Sweetness and Light" (Single, 1990)  Fugazi, "Long Division" (from Steady Diet of Nothing, 1991)  My Bloody Valentine, "Soon" (from Loveless, 1991)  Poster Children, "If you See Kay" (from Daisy Chain Reaction, 1991)  Superchunk, "Throwing Things" (from No Pocky for Kitty, 1991)  Swans, "Love Will Save You" (from White Light from the Edge of Infinity, 1991)  Helmet "Unsung" (from Meantime, 1992)  Sonic Youth "Theresa's Sound World" (from Dirty, 1992)  Morrissey, "You're Gonna to Need Someone on Your Side (from Your Arsenal, 1992)  Pavement "Conduit for Sale" (from Slanted and Enchanted, 1992)  The Smashing Pumpkins, "Disarm" (from Siamese Dream, 1993)  The Breeders, "Cannonball" (from Last Splash, 1993)  Morphine "Cure for Pain" (from Cure for Pain, 1993)  Mercury Rev "Snorry Mouth" (from Boces, 1993)  PJ Harvey, "50 Ft. Queenie" (from Rid of Me, 1993)  Blur, "Girls & Boys" (from Parklife, 1994)  The Cure, "Burn" (from The Crow Soundtrack, 1994)  Radiohead, "Fake Plastic Trees" (from The Bends, 1995)  The Flaming Lips, "This Here Giraffe" (from Clouds Taste Metallic, 1995)  Yo La Tengo "Blue Line Swinger" (from Electr-O-Pura, 1995)  Dandy Warhols, "Ride" (from Dandys Rule, Okay?, 1995)   Butthole Surfers, "Pepper" (from Electric Larryland, 1996)  Brain Jonestown Massacre, "Straight Up and Down" (from Take It From the Man, 1996)  Tortiose "Djed" (from Millions Now Living Will Never Die, 1996)  Modest Mouse "Cowboy Dan" (from the Lonesome Crowded West, 1997)  Spiritualized, "Come Together" (from Ladies and Gentlemen, We Are Floating in Space, 1997)  Yo La Tengo, "The Lie and How We Told It" (from I Can Hear the Heart Beating as One", 1998)  Neutral Milk Hotel, "Holland 1945" (from In the Aeroplane Over the Sea, 1998)  Spoon, "Car Radio" (from A Series of Sneaks, 1998)  The Flaming Lips "What is the Light?" (from The Soft Bulletin, 1999)

Martin Fox did a lot of the heavy lifting on this answer. A lot of those songs brought back fond memories. Anyhow, here is a scattering of postcards from my teens in the 90’s in no order whatsoever. At the Drive In: 198d (1999) Why? Vaya, is easily one of the most critically overlooked albums of all time. If you listen to what Omar Rodriguez-Lopez is doing with his guitar, you’ll appreciate what a gift this band really was.  Soul Coughing: Mr Bitterness (1994) A guy that worked at Strawberries music store told me that if I didn’t like this album, Ruby Vroom, I could bring it back. I never brought it back. Why? Lyrics like these: leaning up against the wallI will lash out dancing like a madman when you're goneI will spit the blue flame and hurl my glass against the wall  G Love and the Special Sauce: Blues Music (1994) Why? This band put one of the most incredible shows I had ever seen… including 20 foot tall dancing puppets brought by a local art collective. Also, I’m native to the Philly area. These guys are princes, and their sounds on record do not do them enough justice for how good they really are.  The Kostars: Don’t Know Why (1995) If you like Lucious Jackson and Ween and find it hard to imagine a world in which they joined together for a song… this is the your song. This album, Classics With a K, is a top to bottom musical adventure. FANTASTIC memories here.  Eric’s Trip: The Stove (1993) This particular song of of the album, Love Tara, brings me closest to actually feeling nostalgic and all gooey-huey misty eyed about it. Coffee never smelled as good to me as it did around this time. I don’t know why.  Dismemberment Plan: Survey Says! (1995) This was a band that opened up for another band who I came to see. I forget who that band is now because I became a D-Plan fan that day, and that is all that matters. This was the song they opened up with. My ass is probably still somewhere on the wall of the Trocadero (yes, I mean they blew it off).  To be continued…

Alternative Rock was the eventual name given and accepted for the underground college music scene of the 1980's. Bands like R.E.M., The Cure, Jane's Addiction and Bauhaus, among others, were recording and touring incessantly in order to develop a following. They were releasing music on small, independent labels and getting airplay by college radio stations where a rabid following developed for a new music that was well outside the established mainstream. By the 1990's, the major labels recognized the marketability of these artists and started signing them to big label contracts that immediately brought the power of their promotional mechanisms to the genre. Bands were being sought and signed as fast as the major labels could acquire them. New music from NYC, LA, Boston, Chicago, and the up-and-coming Seattle scene were thought highly marketable and corporate radio stations were even reformatting their programming to showcase the new Alternative. It was a great time. So much new music hit the airwaves, and many of these bands have survived until today. Even among those that didn't make it, the influence of their perspective and style is felt now in the newest Pop and Alternative offerings. My playlist from the 90's has to include some of the most influential of the period and just one or two that are just guilty pleasures. Nirvana: “Smells Like Teen Spirit”  Pearl Jam: “Jeremy”  Alice In Chains: “Would”  Soundgarden: “Fell On Black Days”  Bush: “Swallowed”  Smashing Pumpkins: “1979″  Fuel: “Bittersweet”  Radiohead: “Creep”  Oasis: “Wonderwall”  The Verve Pipe: “The Freshman”  Oh, man, there's so many more I loved, but I hope this will suffice for now.

What the World Needs Now by Cracker from their self-titled debut.  Man On the Moon by R.E.M. from "Automatic for the People".  Mondays by Wilco from "Being There".  Can't Let Go by Lucinda Williams from "Car Wheels On A Gravel Road".   Waiting For the Sun by The Jayhawks from "Hollywood Town Hall".   Fight For Your Mind is the title cut from Ben Harper's 1995 album.   Kool Thing from Sonic Youth's "Goo".   Seether by Veruca Salt from "American Thighs".

What are some of the best 90s alternative rock songs? In 1991, Matthew Sweet released the album Girlfriend, one of the greatest alternative rock albums of the 1990’s. In addition to Sweet, the album features the guitar work of Robert Quine (Richard Hell and Voidoids), Richard Lloyd (Television), Lloyd Cole (Lloyd Cole and the Commotions), and Ivan Julian (Richard Hell, the Lovelies, the Clash). The opening song, “Divine Intervention” is apparently about Sweet’s then recent divorce.  The song “Girlfriend” was released as a single from the album, and showcases Robert Quine’s guitar work to good effect.
